hasVariant.name: Code RSC Disc Brake
hasVariant.description: Buy the SRAM Code RSC Disc Brake online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody:
I used to love my Shimano XT 2 piston brakes. The bite was fierce. Except a lot of times I’d slide  off the trail. Those tires would lock up like a mofo. I used to think that was the indicator of a great brake. (I’ve never owned 4 piston Shimano brakes but from one I read it’s similar). 

Then I bought a bike that came stock with Code RSC’s. Gone was the fierce bite.  I was bummed. I wondered how these things would ever stop me. I didn’t know what modulation was. The  I started riding some good downhill and realized how good these brakes were. Code RSC’s deliver confident power, just over a longer linear curve. My old Shimano’s delivered power all at once, or more progressively. Zero to hero in .04 seconds. RSC’s take a little longer to find alol if it’s power. But, ever since I’ve had the Codes, I’ve never locked up the tires and slid off the trail. Never. It’s easy to get to the power zone but hard to lock up the tires. I’ve found that to be a great thing. It feels like my finger tip has complete control over how much or how little bite I want. If and when you do finally do lock up, it’s anxiety inducing and you realize how grateful you are that it takes a lot of effort to lock them up.

I really like the linear modulated power of Code RSC’s. The R’s and RS’s don’t have the same power. The levers aren’t bearing actuated and don’t have a smooth feel. Shimano wins in having a greater assortment of good brakes. SRAM has one great brake in its lineup and that’s the RSC’s.
review.name: If you’re going to go SRAM, go Code RSC.

review.reviewBody: SRAM brakes are an acquired taste. I feel that the bite point of the CODE RSC is the most consistent. The Guide and Level are borderline unusable in my opinion. The Code R is good, but but great. The RSC performs exactly how you would want and expect.
review.name: Best Brakes in the SRAM lineup

review.reviewBody:
Whenever I see comments about how "SRAM brakes suck" I can't help but to think these people have either never used them or set them up wrong. Maybe the lower end models but all cheap brakes kinda suck.

The Code RSC's came on my Scott Genius and they have always works flawlessly. I can feel every bit of modulation against the rotor and always feel in control. I won't be deviating from Codes anytime soon.
review.name: Excellent

name: Code RSC Disc Brake

review.itemreviewed: Capilene Cool Lightweight Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
review.reviewBody: this little shirt is a travel partner.  great to climb in.  perfect fit.
review.name: it’s so right

review.itemreviewed: Capilene Cool Lightweight Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
review.reviewBody:
The order was processed very quickly and arrived on time 
This shirt is very light, just perfect for using it in hot weather
review.name: Fast delivery

review.itemreviewed: Capilene Cool Lightweight Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
review.reviewBody: I've owned this shirt for almost 3 years, and it's still in exactly the same condition as when I bought it. It's lightweight and comfortable, and always keeps me cool in warm weather. It's exceptionally quick-drying and fits me very well.
review.name: Great warm-weather base layer

review.itemreviewed: Capilene Cool Lightweight Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
review.reviewBody:
Still my favorite shirt even though I don't like some of the changes.  
What is still great:
-Lightweight
-Quick drying
-Fabric feel
-Versatility
What changed (from older versions):
-No more thumb loops.  
-The cut is different in the arms, sleeves ride up a bit.
-Bit more delicate, snags easier.

I have 3 older versions and 2 of the newer renditions.  Wear these shirts year round because they are that versatile.
review.name: Still my favorite shirt even though....

name: Capilene Cool Lightweight Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's

review.reviewBody: This Smth helmet fits much more naturally and comfortably on my head vs the Bontrager helmet I had been using.  I didn't know what I was missing.
review.name: Great fit, no fuss, finally

review.reviewBody:
I’m a skier and know several other skiers and snowboarders who swear by their Smith helmets. When I saw the Smith MIPS helmet on sale I had to purchase it. Very comfortable and solid fit. Exceptional cushioning with no tight areas just a solid feel. 

What I really like is you can put in the helmet and take it by just tightening or loosening the main helmet strap. No guessing. 

Also, I measured the circumference of my head and used the “size chart” and the fit is so close that I barely 
barely had to use the ratchet adjustment. 

I’m a mountain biker and this helmet works great. No movement of the helmet over rough ground or rocks. It’s just part of the head going for a ride.
review.name: Incredible helmet !!

review.reviewBody: I purchased this helmet to use as a commuter/light gravel helmet. The straps rub on the back of my ears no matter how I adjust them, making the helmet unusable. Its a shame because the helmet fits my head well and looks decent.
review.name: Can’t handle the straps

review.reviewBody: Although I would like other colours in XL (in bike helmets), this one fits great. Smith really needs to make other bike helmets in size XL. Ski helmets they do, but not many bike helmets.
review.name: A Smith helmet that fits my noggin!

review.reviewBody: My husband said he doesn’t like the straps , they are too hard to adjust.
review.name: Straps are too hard to adjust

review.reviewBody: A little bit too tight. And I have to pay the shipping to send it back. So I say to myself, Rey bad move to buy an helmet without trying it. Bad experiences
review.name: A little bit too tight.

review.reviewBody: Switched to this product for the MIPS and how sturdy it appeared. I only had the opportunity to wear the helmet for 8 minutes before a distracted driver turned left into my path. The helmet did what it was suppose to, I had no injury to my head. I will be replacing this helmet with the same!
review.name: Great Protection

review.reviewBody: I like the style, fit and comfort of the helmet. It was definitely an upgrade over my old helmet which was questionable in all these categories.
review.name: I like the style, fit

review.reviewBody: Nice, light and well-fitting, but the strap system is terrible. The little buckles will tear your fingers up trying to pry them open and no matter what you do, you’ll never get them to lay flat.
review.name: Nice for the price, but …

review.reviewBody: Won't be going for a ride outside until March, but I like the quality, the fit and how it looks.
review.name: Won't be going for a

name: Signal Mips Helmet

hasVariant.description: Buy the Smith Shift MAG ChromaPop Sunglasses online or shop all Accessories from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: My new go to on bluebird days. Great fit, clarity. Now wife wants ‘em!
review.name: My new go to on

review.reviewBody: I use these for mtb biking and work. First week I had them they stayed nice and firm on my hat. After a week they started falling off my head. They fell once and got scratch up super easily. Not satisfied at all. Save your money.
review.name: IMO not worth it

review.reviewBody: I definitely have a small head, no doubt about about that. But they bounced around a lot and don't fit my temples and feel too flexy side to side and I can't keep them steady when riding really fast in chunky terrain
review.name: Love - but fit could be better

review.reviewBody: Even though I purchased these at a steep discount, I will return them. They feel incredibly flimsy. I found the lenses hard to swap out. Even after I practiced and practiced I still found them difficult to change. When closing the arms of the sunglasses, the Smith logo on the side almost pops out on its own. I fear this would lead to an accidental release of the lenses. I couldn't change the lenses without getting fingerprints on both sets of lenses, which defeats the purpose of using these on multi-day bikepacking events. The clear lens already had a nick in it too. They also felt like they were going to slip right off my head. I couldn't take them out biking, because I already knew they wouldn't work for me. I like the shape of the lens, and they seem to provide good coverage. I know they would end up broke or scratched in about a month with how hard I am on gear. I'll keep looking for a pair of sunglasses with better fit, quality, and functionality because the Shift Mag lacks all of those features.
review.name: Not Impressed at All

review.reviewBody: Good coverage, light, and comfortable for road cycling
review.name: Great for road cycling

review.reviewBody:
I really like the fit of the Shift MAG, and am impressed with how light they feel. Good field of view, and top shelf optics.
I do find it a bit of a task to line up the lense with the bottom edge of the frame, but overall, I would buy these glasses again and am very happy with them!
review.name: I really like the fit

review.reviewBody: These are great glasses if you want light feeling glasses that don’t put much pressure on the bridge of your nose. The lens that adapts to light works great as well.
review.name: These are great glasses if

review.reviewBody: They worked good until the magnetic mechanism that holds the lenses broke under light pressure in my pocket. Smiths quality has declined in recent years (I’ve noticed this with their helmets as well as sunglasses) and these sunnies are proof of that. Not related to these glasses, I had a horrendous experience with their customer support team over a separate order. So between these breaking on me and my horrible experience I wont be buying anything Smith ever again.
review.name: Kinda good but definitely not durable

review.reviewBody: They sit really weird on my face. The lens isn’t that dark and I find myself squinting due to the brightness. It’s almost seems like the lens isn’t the one I ordered. A different pair of sunglasses I had (before they broke due to being cheaply made) came with supposedly the same lens but they were darker. Overall I’m not satisfied and wish I could return them. The nose piece does adjust but I find that the perfect setting is in between the two positions. If the glasses were lower on my face, I think I could roll with them. They sit high and kind of lean forward. It’s weird. I would say that I’m most likely done ordering Smith sunglasses. My snow goggles aren’t the best either and the lenses often warp my vision. Real pricey products for a huge lack of performance.
review.name: Nope.

review.reviewBody: Outstanding fit and so light weight. You forget your wearing them. Perfect!
review.name: Outstanding fit and so light

name: Shift MAG ChromaPop Sunglasses

review.reviewBody: Been on many day rides with this since I bought it. It’s a nice bag with the perfect capacity. It does feel a little heavy loaded up with water. My gripe is that it comes loose when riding. At some point it’s flopping around and I’ll have to stop and cinch it down again. I’m an average size guy, maybe on the skinny side. Would be nice if it came with a clip or something. I use a safety pin now.
review.name: Nice bag BUT…

review.reviewBody: this is my first lumbar pack, i've been biking with the same camelback for almost 20 years. I really like this: my shoulders and back are cooler, this pack is comfortable. i like how the nozzle clips to the belt with a magnet, so its easy to drink while pedaling. This is large enough for me to ride 2-3 hours as long as I just need the usual (light jacket, couple snacks, water, toolkit, chapstick, dog bowl, gummy candies, car keys). I love how the hip pocket fits my iphone 12 mini.
review.name: nice lumbar pack for mtn biking

review.reviewBody: A friend recommended this to me, and it was just what I was looking for. Comfortable, carries what I need, it's my new go to for a short hike or bike ride.
review.name: Just what I was looking for

review.reviewBody: I have used this probably on every ride since I first got it. The hip pack fits perfectly and stays pretty secure but sometimes I do have to tighten it if the terrain gets a little rough.  Ive used the Hydrapak probably only a handful of times on longer rides but most of the time I ride without it. The pack holds a spare tube for a 29er, a hand pump, a multi tool, Stans dart, wallet, car keys, snacks and gels with plenty of room to spare if you need it. I have had it covered in mud and I just rinse it off and throw it in the washer and comes out looking brand new again. I highly recommend this hip pack.
review.name: Great for the trail

review.reviewBody: I used this 3 times so far. A long XC weekend in Brown County and on 2 long days on a gravel bike. A big plus is that the weight of gear and water is off of your hands and shoulders and on your hips. I think it helps with overall fatigue. Holds quite a bit of gear for a long day. The only negative is if you hit jumps it can get a bit annoying because it bounces. It can also be a bit difficult to drink from on really rough terrain, but that?s not an issue much.
review.name: XC and Gravel bike must

name: Hot Laps 5L Lumbar Pack

review.reviewBody: I've been wearing knee pads while riding for over 10 years.  I've used a lot of different pads.  They all have trade-offs.  No matter what they are going to make your knees hot and sweaty to some degree and that is going to be balanced by the protection they offer in a crash.  I read a good review of these and thought I'd give them a try even though they are about 30% more than competitive products from Leatt, Fox, and Pearl Izumi.  I tried them on and I don't think they are going to stay in place during a crash and protect enough of my knee.  They were not all that lightweight either.  They may pedal well but if my knee is still bruised and bloody after a crash why bother.    I'd go with the Leatt Airflex over these and I'd probably go for something with a little more protection in any case.  Large also seemed a little loose.
review.name: Not impressed for the price

review.reviewBody: I originally ordered the POC VPD 2.0 pads (in both a knee and elbow pad), however, I found them to be really hot. I switched to the POC joint VPD system pads, and boy am I glad I did. They are WAY comfortable. I mostly trail ride, but wanted a pad with good protection. These fit the bill. They don't get too hot, and I honestly forgot I was wearing them. Had no issues pedaling in them either. Overall great pad! Good job POC.
review.name: Great Knee Pads

review.reviewBody: Not terrible to climb in, but I wouldn't go on trail rides with them. I mainly bought them for when I'm riding freeride jumps, and rougher downhills. Comfort wise, I'm EXTREMELY picky as I live in Arizona where it can hit 115 degrees easily in the summer. These are very comfortable compared to similarly protective pads. I wish the thigh closure was a bit looser, but I understand that I have XC legs.
review.name: Comfortable and Protective

name: Joint VPD System Knee Pad

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody:
One of the best bottle I have ever had, keeps my coffee hot all day long and the tumbler is an added advantage when I want to share my coffee with my loved ones.
The bottle has become a part of my life, it goes wherever I go.
Thanks Camelbak for making such a wonderful bottle.
review.name: One of the best bottle

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody: Everything is perfect with the bottle design and cup size. However, the capacity is little bit not enough as it could be filled with Venti oz (24 oz) if possible so I can order the cold coffee in my tumbler bottle.
review.name: Very pretty and useful with included cup.

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody: It’s the best mug I’ve ever had. I love that if I just want a small cup of coffee, I’ve got the lower cup and the roll lid, and if I’ve got a long day, I can bring coffee from home and have it all day, super versatile. I have both the larger and smaller versions, and this 22/16oz is perfect. The base could be a smidge wider, it fits a little loosely in my Gen 3 Tacoma cup holders, but all things considered, it’s a super awesome mug.
review.name: Best mug ever :)

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody:
Perfect fit for love of coffee! I use this everyday! Keeps coffee hot for hours and is so convenient! 
I take it to my local coffee shop ( Owl Eye Roasters) for fresh coffee nearly everyday. It’s been a great conversation piece and honestly for what you pay for it, it is a great value. I like what I have as far as Yeti stuff goes but I will be buying camelbak products instead. Nothing wrong with Yeti, camelbak is just a better value in my opinion. The 22oz Capacity is great but I would like to see something with a larger capacity for longer road trips.
review.name: Incredible

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody: This smart design makes it so I always have a go cup for coffee or a beer when traveling. Love it!
review.name: Perfect travel buddy

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody: It’s genius. We like to bike early in the morning, take coffee and a muffin along, then stop along the way for a relaxed breakfast. The Multibev 22 fits in the bike water bottle holder & we each can have a drinking vessel out Share the cup.
review.name: Cup & coffee all to go!

review.itemreviewed: MultiBev Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated 22oz/16oz Cup
review.reviewBody: I own a camelback and another competitor. I use both. I believe that camelbak has nailed the size of the bottle and the size of the cup. I don’t really use the cup cap. Fits in cup holders and it is dishwasher safe.
review.name: Good size

review.reviewBody: Really good!

description: Buy the Thule Epos 2 With Lights online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Epos 2 With Lights
hasVariant.description: Buy the Thule Epos 2 With Lights online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: The bike rack is very easy to set up and holds the bikes very firmly in place. The drop down feature also works extremely well.  The light weight and folding of the rack when not in use makes storage very easy.  Very happy with my purchase.
review.name: Travel freedom

review.reviewBody: Happy with my purchase. Unit is not as long as I thought it was. Checked to make sure before purchasing as I have a very long wheelbase e-bike. Would have liked to see tire guides a little higher to prevent the front wheel twisting once it is strapped down. Problem solved by making sure the front wheel axle doesn’t protrude past the end of the guide rails. Once you realize there is an order to strapping your bike down the unit works well and holds the bike in a very stable position. I really like the locks on the upright top tube clamps as it makes it extremely difficult for someone to remove the bike from the rack and you don’t have to fiddle with pulling out cable locks. Like that the top tube clamps are telescopic; much superior to the Easy Fold rack, with fixed clamps that made carrying two bikes a massive headache. Also really like the lights and license plate position, although it does take a little while to realize your vehicle is a couple of feet longer than it was. No more tickets for having a covered license plate. Bikes are easy to load and rack carries two heavy e-bikes in a stable manner. Recommended.
review.name: Good solid product

review.reviewBody: I had a bad experience last summer with a bike getting loose on the carrier and due to the velcro straps on the tires, it was the only thing that saved the bike and any cars behind us on I-75! I have been hauling our Pedego bikes in my van and it was very challenging. I opted to go with this carrier and I am very pleased.
review.name: Thule Epos 2

review.reviewBody: Disappointed that Thule did not rig the light cables inside the supports as the cables now are easily detached from the unit.  Also Thule should have installed a permanent ring to attach extra locking cables.
review.name: Like the rack as it’s easy to attach to hitch.

review.reviewBody: I like the wheels that allow you to roll the carrier from my garage to the vehicle.  The tail lights and license plate holder address safety concerns since my old rack blocked the vehicle tail lights and license plate.  It would be nice if Thule developed a bike cover that allowed me to cover my e-bikes without blocking the racks tail lights and license plate.
review.name: Rollers and Tail Lights

review.reviewBody:
Used our Epos for the first time. Fantastic.
Received the rack and organized all the tools needed to put the rack together, which has always been the case with Thule. Not so. Surprised and ecstatic when I opened the box to find it was completely assembled and to top it all off, a completely tool-less installation.
Not sure why it took so long to get his rack to the North American market, but we did wait it out and now have, probably the best hitch mounted bike rack ever.
review.name: Buy This Rack

review.reviewBody: I would have given 5 stars but my rack came with a lighting flaw that is forcing me to make a warranty claim.  Aside from the lighting I’m very pleased.  The design and execution are terrific.  Its top-dollar cost is reflected in its top-of-class quality.
review.name: Excellent design. Easy to load/unload. Very secure

review.reviewBody: Having used the bike rack for the past 4 months I'll agree that the loading, securing, and fit for e-bikes is excellent. Unfortunately everything else is an epic fail, especially for a very expensive bike rack. Starting with trying to attach the rack to your hitch, you had better have a lot of patience and a lot of strength to put this into your receiver. Does it fit snugly after it's seated? Absolutely. Is it a complete pain to put in and take out? Absolutely. It's designed to expand once placed inside the receiver, however getting it into the receiver is an exercise in patience. Flipping the lever over to shrink the receiver is supposed to allow the bike rack to smoothly slide in, but even after greasing the receiver, it is still very very difficult to slip in. Which echoes when you try to pull it back out. Rocking back and forth 20-30 times before you can actually extract the rack is really unacceptable.  Secondarily and frankly most important to me is that the light kit is not properly engineered to signal my Jeep that the lights are actually working. Every time I tap the brakes or turn on a turn signal, I get a warning from my Jeep saying that the lights are out. Of course, Thule is pointing fingers at Jeep and Jeep is pointing fingers at Thule. Meanwhile, I'm a distracted driver who spent hundreds diagnosing at my dealer only to end up with this problem persisting. And finally, whomever created that cover should be shot. I really enjoy after wrangling with my bike rack for a half hour to get it off the hitch spending another half hour trying to put that darn cover on it. Does it carry bikes? Well yes. Does everything else cause me to wish I never bought it, absolutely.
review.name: Carries bikes, fails at everything else

review.reviewBody:
My previous bike rack was a T2 Pro XTR.   I added a light bar to hook up to my trailer hitch wiring and thought I had it made.

Then I saw the Epos 2 with Lights.  The reviews that I read almost made me pass.  The biggest concern being what some said about how low it sat.  I looked over the photos and decided that it would like sit at the same height as the T2 Pro XTR.

Not enough words to say how happy I am that I upgraded to the Epos 2.  The built in lighting is critical to me.  Beyond that; in comparison to the T2 Pro XTR the Epos 2 is lighter, easier to load and unload; holds more weight (max and per bike) and takes almost 8 inches less in distance behind my car.

And yes, it sits at the same height as the T2 Pro XTR.  

The extra expense is worth every penny. That goes for the Hi Performance Lock as well.  You need one for each bike; the Hi Performance lock, as well as the Epos 2 is much easier to use and way more flexible in how a bike can be loaded that the T2 Pro XTR.
review.name: Awesome step up from the T2 Pro XTR

review.reviewBody: Although a previous review and respons from thule about the fold up feature doesn't exist due to safety reasons, the rack isnt wider than most vehicles and doesn't obscure the lights, only the license plate. Unfortunately the design is somewhat flawed, in my opinion, because everytime you use the rack you have to relocate your license plate. For an active bike user that's not practical at all. Parking with an SUV with the Epos 3 unfolded isn't even possible in any parking space at all whatsoever. The rack either sticks out 3 feet or the front of your vehicle sticks out 3 feet. Vision from the side of the vehicle for incoming parking lot traffic is obscured because most people aren't looking for a rack. Everytime you park and unload bikes the rack and plate needs to be removed and relocated. That's 4 times every time you go out to one location. Install at house, remove at destination, install at destination, remove at house for storage again
review.name: Doesnt fold up and lock in.

name: Epos 2 With Lights

review.itemreviewed: Olympus Mid GTX 2 Hiking Shoe - Women's
review.reviewBody: I have the previous Olympus 4 and I still love them. However this 6 is super fantastic and even better that the 4 but wins over the Olympus 5! I never liked the 5 and had to return because they just felt weird,. The cushion in the back of the heel made the shoe feel smaller and you had to size down for things to work. That was the 5. But these 6 really are the top! I was afraid at first it would be too much height with the cushion and may be wobbly but it is stable and firm. This is really the top version of the Olympus the 6. And this color is out of this world! . The laces are wide and tie perfectly. I did not have to double tie because they stay tied. The other always like most have to double tie tie or else they untie after awhile. The new color of this shoe is gorgeous. It looks stunning and expensive which it is. I have been very picky upgrading and this is perfect. I like the Olympus because of how stable. I have the black in 4 because I can do anything like my yard. But this color is real classy. I don't want to get it dirty. Love it Love it!!!! Oh I am 75 years old with lots of arthritis and problems and this Olympus 6 is very very comfortable and has helped my problems with arthritis>
review.name: Fantastic Olympus 6

name: Olympus Mid GTX 2 Hiking Shoe - Women's

review.itemreviewed: MILLE GT Jersey C2 EVO - Men's
review.reviewBody: Finally a jersey made for American riders who aren’t 130 lbs.  I’m 5’-9” , 170 lbs and the extra large fits perfectly.  Great hot weather jersey.  I love the fit and finish. Would definitely buy again
review.name: Great fit and performance

review.itemreviewed: MILLE GT Jersey C2 EVO - Men's
review.reviewBody:
I love Assos clothing and always buy it when I can. I fit a large or medium bib and a large jersey. That's how it's  been for many years. 

I bought a large jersey and the fit is really off. While I have wide shoulders, I don't know who this is for. My main gripe is it's far too wide in the lats area (under my arms). I'm not skinny, but this is for a weight lifter sized person, as best as I can see. 

In short, assuming the jersey I was sent is how they are all cut, this won't fit anyone who rides with this gear.
review.name: Great Jersey, if it fits!

review.itemreviewed: MILLE GT Jersey C2 EVO - Men's
review.reviewBody: ASSOS simply the BEST, Quality. last forever
review.name: plain and simple

review.itemreviewed: MILLE GT Jersey C2 EVO - Men's
review.reviewBody:
I am a large Rapha and this was small for me. Nice jersey - just too small. And when I went back to get another - the XL were sold out. 

I am 183cm and 165lbs. I should not need a Large, let alone an XL. 

Beware.
review.name: Nice Jersey, but it runs small.

name: MILLE GT Jersey C2 EVO - Men's

hasVariant.description: Buy the Ocun Ozone Climbing Shoe online or shop all Climb from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: These shoes are excellent at edging. I wore these shoes on Grand Ole Opry and Sarchasm and the Ozones performed magically. Both of those routes are two of Colorado's most proud technical test pieces. A fair bit of foot wizardry is required to send them and these shoes were the right ones for the job. I felt comfortable, or at least as comfortable as you can be standing on micro feet up high on a cliff, trusting my feet on little dime edges.
review.name: On the Edge

review.reviewBody: Love these shoes for when I need a bit of a stiffer edge outside. They did amazing on my trip to Ceuse and I trusted my feet on even the shiniest and most slippery limestone. Really comfortable too, one of my favorite thing about Ocun's high performance shoes is that I can leave them on for my entire session easily.
review.name: SO good for outdoor!

name: Ozone Climbing Shoe
